title: Cell Phone Bans, School Funding, and What’s Next for Georgia Classrooms
text:
cell phone bans, school funding, and what’s next for georgia classrooms overview:
- the georgia legislature discussed bills related to cell phone bans in schools and changes to the education funding formula.

key actions:
- **sb 381**: directs education funding through the quality basic education (qbe) formula to provide additional support for students living in poverty, in foster care, or in unstable housing.

bills introduced (first reading):
- hb 109: extends the cell phone ban from grades k-8 to grades 9-12, with some exceptions for off-campus activities.

notable moments:
- discussions between republican representative scott hilton and democratic senator rashon kemp on the positive impacts of the k-8 cell phone ban and the need to expand it to high schools.
- mentions of potential pushback from some parents on school safety concerns, which were addressed by consulting the safety community.
- debate on allowing school-issued devices for educational purposes versus banning personal cell phones.

**overview:** the subcommittee discussed and considered amendments to house bill 364, which aims to establish a panel of experts to evaluate and recommend compensation for individuals who have been wrongfully convicted. the bill would provide a range of $50,000 to $100,000 in compensation.

- **hr 364:** legislation to create an expert panel to evaluate and recommend compensation for the wrongly convicted

- consideration of an amendment to allow for annuity payments for awards over $1.5 million
- emphasis on ensuring the compensation is exempt from taxation

**votes:** the subcommittee unanimously voted to adopt the amendment allowing for annuity payments.

**attendance:** quorum was present for the subcommittee meeting.

title: 3/16/23 - Committee on State and Local Governmental Operations
text:
3/16/23 - committee on state and local governmental operations overview:
this georgia legislative committee session focused on a bill (hb 254) to modernize laws related to legal organs in the state. the key discussion centered around addressing issues with legal ads not being properly published by newspapers serving as legal organs, as well as the declining number of local newspapers.

key actions:
none detected.

bills introduced (first reading):
none detected.

notable moments:
- representative jacobs presented hb 254, which aims to address problems with legal ads not being properly published by newspapers serving as legal organs, as well as the declining number of local newspapers.
- representative jacobs noted that this bill does not change any of the requirements on legal organs, but allows for digital ad placement to count as the first day of publication if the legal organ fails to publish the ad as required.
- a representative from columbia county provided examples of issues they have faced with legal ads not being published properly by their legal organ.
- committee members discussed the challenges posed by newspapers going out of business or shifting to digital-only formats, and the potential to explore a statewide digital repository for legal ads.
- there was discussion around the increase in ad rates for legal organs, with the representative noting it had been around 30 years since the last increase.

title: 3/21/23 - Senate Committee on Appropriations
text:
3/21/23 - senate committee on appropriations overview:
- the senate appropriations committee considered several key bills, including hb 611 and the fy 2024 budget bill (hb 19).
- there was notable discussion around preserving the general assembly's role in appropriating settlement funds and addressing issues in the state's medicaid, child welfare, and mental health systems.

key actions:
- **hb 611**: requires that any settlement agreement or proceeds from a settlement agreement be appropriated by the general assembly after june 1, 2023.
- **hb 19**: the senate appropriations committee substitute for the fy 2024 budget bill. key provisions include:
  - restoring medicaid utilization cost cuts
  - shoring up the state health benefit plan by $1 billion
  - addressing structural deficits at child care institutions
  - increasing reimbursement rates for the "babies can't wait" early intervention program
  - providing over $40 million to address mental health staffing and facility needs
  - funding 500 new comp waivers
  - fully funding dyslexia screening for k-3 students a year earlier than required by sb 48

bills introduced (first reading):
- none mentioned

notable moments:
- discussion around the need to preserve the general assembly's role in appropriating settlement funds, particularly related to ongoing opioid litigation.
- remarks on the senate version of the budget bill aligning more closely with the governor's proposal than the house version, while still incorporating some house priorities.

votes:
- hb 611 passed by substitute.

- a quorum was present.

title: Ban on transgender athletes playing in girls' sports passes in Georgia House
text:
ban on transgender athletes playing in girls' sports passes in georgia house ## overview

the georgia house session discussed and passed sb1, a bill that bans transgender athletes from participating in girls' sports in the state. the debate featured input from both supporters and opponents of the legislation.

## key actions

**sb1**: ban on transgender athletes playing in girls' sports in georgia

## bills introduced (first reading)

none noted.

## notable moments

- clergy and parents of transgender children spoke against sb1 during the debate.
- supporters argued the bill would ensure a "level playing field" for female athletes.
- it was noted that there are currently zero transgender students competing in k-12 sports in georgia.

## votes

no recorded votes detected.

## attendance

quorum was present for the discussion.

## adjournment

the timing of adjournment and next session date were not provided. all we're looking for is simply a level playing field,
meaning when a female athlete steps on the playing field,
that there is no advantage other than fair and clean competition.
we had clergy speak against sb1.
we had parents of transgender children speak against sb1.
not a single coach, not a single athletic organization,
not a one, zero, which, incidentally, is the amount of transgender students competing
in k through 12 sports in georgia, zero.

title: Capitol Report Day 25 02/28/25
text:
capitol report day 25 02/28/25 # georgia capitol report day 25 - 02/28/25

## overview
this session saw the passage of a bill to expand the georgia promise scholarship to the biological and adopted children of fostering families, a move aimed at incentivizing foster care. the house also passed a bill to modernize the state's 911 call center system. additionally, senate republicans filed legislation to further investigate the new georgia project and its founder stacey abrams over alleged financial misconduct, despite a previous investigation by the state ethics commission.

## key actions
**hb 423**: bill to implement geographic information systems in 911 call centers to improve emergency response times.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills detected.

## notable moments
- debate over the foster care scholarship bill, with democrats objecting over concerns about potential misuse of funds and the lack of a similar scholarship for foster children themselves.
- senate republicans filing legislation to further investigate the new georgia project and stacey abrams, despite a previous investigation by the state ethics commission.

## votes
- the foster care scholarship bill passed 32-22 along party lines.

## attendance
a quorum was present for the legislative proceedings.

## adjournment
the legislature adjourned and will reconvene on monday for day 26, leading up to cross-over day on thursday. the senate debated a bill that would allow the biological and adopted children of fostering
families to access the $6,500 georgia promise scholarship.
this is an important step to ensure that those people that take care of the most vulnerable
in our population have an initial incentive to do so.
democrats objected because of the threat to families misusing the funds, as well as
we are not giving that same scholarship to the very foster children they will have in
their households.
bill passed 32 to 22 along party lines. across the hall, the house passed a bill that would
modernize the state's 911 call center system. house bill 423 would implement geographic information
systems to more accurately locate the caller and reduce emergency response times.
whether it be folks in rural georgia, suburban georgia, or in our urban centers, all across
our state, we see a great need to utilize current technology.
also today, senate republicans filed legislation to investigate the new georgia project, and
its founder, stacey abrams, for alleged financial misconduct.
the state ethics commission already investigated and levied a large fine on the organization.
but lieutenant governor bert jones says that more scrutiny is needed.
democrats say it's a waste of time.
lawmakers return on monday for day 26, as the lead up to cross-over day on thursday continues.
for gbb news, i'm sarah callis at the state capitol.

title: 3/16/23 - Committee on Rules
text:
3/16/23 - committee on rules overview:
- the georgia legislature's committee on rules session on 3/16/23 was an active one, with the committee members engaged in discussing and advancing several bills.

key actions:
- **hb 493**: allows nurses at veterans' hospitals to use $500 worth of work at their va as continuing education credits, like other state-licensed nurses.
- **hb 35**: expands the georgia ports authority's jurisdiction to one mile beyond port boundaries.
- **hb 76**: renames the "georgia occupational regulation review commission" to the "georgia occupational regulation review council."
- **hb 91**: requires executors to provide notice to beneficiaries and treats investment/brokerage accounts with named beneficiaries like bank accounts.
- **hb 120**: allows people behind on child support to receive temporary driving permits to go back to work, and cleans up language around dui-drug charges and license reinstatement.
- **hb 183**: updates the population bracket identifying butts county to allow georgia power lease-holders on jackson lake to file homestead exemptions.

none detected

senator parent & senator harrell press conference | donna's law here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia senator parent & senator harrell press conference on donna's law:

**overview**
this press conference focused on the introduction of sb 522, known as "donna's law", which would allow individuals to voluntarily place themselves on a "do not sell" list to prevent them from purchasing firearms during periods of suicidal ideation. the law is named after katrina breeze's mother, donna, who died by suicide after impulsively purchasing a firearm. the senators and advocates highlighted the rising rates of suicide by firearm in georgia and the need for this type of preventative measure.

**key actions**
**sb 522**: donna's law - creates a process for individuals to voluntarily suspend their ability to purchase firearms during periods of suicidal thoughts.

- sb 522: donna's law

- chelsea piot, from the american foundation for suicide prevention, spoke as a suicide loss survivor and in support of the bill.
- the senators emphasized the bipartisan nature of the legislation and their hope to gain broad support.

no votes were taken, as this was an introductory press conference for the bill.

quorum was not mentioned.

title: Capitol Report Day 37 03/28/25
text:
capitol report day 37 03/28/25 here is a summary of the georgia capitol report day 37 03/28/25 session:

**overview**:
the session featured disagreements over a judicial pay raise bill and the state budget, with the senate making changes to the house version that the house did not support. key legislation was passed, including a bill increasing penalties for fentanyl trafficking and protections for in vitro fertilization.

**key actions**:
**hb68**: fiscal year 2026 state budget bill, passed senate with changes from house version

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
none noted

**notable moments**:
- debate over senate amendment to judicial pay raise bill that added increases for governor and other state leaders
- discussion of federal funding changes impacting state budget

**votes**:
- hb68 (state budget): passed senate 48-7

**attendance**:
quorum present

**adjournment**:
session adjourned, with next week being the final week of the legislative session. good evening, i'm sarah callis with the lawmakers capitol report.
in the house, members disagreed to senate changes to house bill 86.
the bill was written to increase pay for some judges, but a senate amendment made yesterday
added significant pay increases for governor brian kemp and other state leaders.
i think that is the discussion we as a body need to have at some point, but we shouldn't
have it as an amendment to a bill in the last two or three days of session.
the house also passed a bill increasing penalties for fentanyl trafficking and gave final approval
to protections for in vitro fertilization.
the senate presented their version of the hb68, the fiscal year 2026 budget, stressing
that money is going to be tighter as covid era federal funds sent to the state are disappearing.
the senate's budget realigns some of the funding you may have seen in the house and it's
a recognition of what we're looking at at the national level. as you know, the federal
government is in a position now to realign its budget, get its fiscal house in order
for the first time in decades. we support that initiative, but it might mean some changes
on the state level. the state prison system had big increases to hire more correctional officers
for pay raises and to acquire new technology
to counter prison contraband.
in education, the senate fully funded
private school vouchers at $140 million,
but cut 28 million from the house
planned to fund disadvantaged students.
the bill was passed 48 to seven
and now goes back to the house.
monday marks the last week of the legislative session
under the gold dome.
for gpb news, i'm sarah callis at the state capitol.

title: Capitol Report Day 34 03/21/25
text:
capitol report day 34 03/21/25 ## overview

the georgia legislature session focused on the debate and passage of senate bill 68, a controversial tort reform bill that included an exception for victims of human trafficking. the session featured a failed amendment to extend protections to children and the elderly, as well as concerns raised by a republican senator about the bill being an "insurance company bailout."

## key actions

**sb 68**: tort reform bill, passed 34-21.

## bills introduced (first reading)

no new bills were introduced.

## notable moments

- attempted amendment to extend protections to children and the elderly failed.
- senator colton moore, a republican, criticized the bill as an "insurance company bailout" with no guarantees of lower rates.
- governor brian kemp praised the legislature's work on the "tough issue."

## votes

**sb 68**: passed 34-21.

## attendance

no quorum issues noted.

## adjournment

lawmakers will return on tuesday for day 35 of the session. good evening, i'm sarah callis with the lawmaker's capitol report.
senate bill 68, the controversial tort reform bill, was back in the senate today after changes
were made in the house, the carved out an exception for victims of human trafficking.
tried to add an amendment before the debate started that would give children an elderly
plaintiffs the same protections as people who have been trafficked.
so let's stand with kids, let's stand with the elderly. why should they not have the same
rights? if they're abused, if they're raped, then people who have been sex trafficked.
why should they not have the same rights?" that amendment failed.
senator john kennedy, who sponsored the bill, said that current laws still provide
many of those protections and weren't needed in the bill.
all of the other causes of actions in georgia law are remain untouched that folks have
available to them. democrats also found an unexpected ally in republican senator colton moore,
who said that while he was all for the premises liabilities addressed in the bill.
because everything else in this piece of legislation is nothing more than an insurance
company bailout. there's no guarantees whatsoever that insurance companies are going to lower their
rates. i think any good business man in the insurance company. now that they've got
this bell out, what are they going to do? they're going to pocket that money, not return it
back to their customers.
sb 68 was passed mostly along party lines, 34 to 21. governor brian kemp spoke afterwards.
i've seen a lot of good legislating around this building over the years on really tough
issues and this rank is right up there with them. it's a great job.
lawmakers return on tuesday for day 35.
for g-pv news, i'm sarah callis at the state capitol.

title: Lawmakers 2026 | Day 2: Income Tax Debate and ICE Protections
text:
lawmakers 2026 | day 2: income tax debate and ice protections here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia lawmakers 2026 | day 2: income tax debate and ice protections session:

## overview
this session focused on legislation related to income taxes, property taxes, and immigration enforcement. senate republicans announced their priorities for the 2026 legislative session, while senate democrats proposed bills aimed at regulating ice agents in georgia.

## key actions
- **sb 204**: originally a democratic bill from 2025 that allowed certain non-violent felonies to be charged by district attorneys without the involvement of a grand jury. the bill was amended to include language from sb 163, which would allow individual gun owners to bring legal action against local governments who they feel infringed on their second amendment rights.
- **sb 389**: proposed by senate democrats, would require ice agents to remove their masks and properly identify themselves during arrests.
- **proposed bills**: democrats also proposed bills to allow civil lawsuits against ice and require a warrant for arrests in schools, hospitals, and churches.

## bills introduced (first reading)
- sb 390: proposed by senate democrats, would require legislative approval for national guard deployment in georgia.
- sb 192: not mentioned in the transcript, but likely introduced during the session.

## notable moments
- senate democrats held a press conference to announce their legislation affecting immigration enforcement, calling for ice agents to "unmask" and be held accountable.
- republican lawmakers criticized the democrats' proposed bills, saying they were unnecessary and that law enforcement leaders should make decisions about tactical gear, not legislators.

## votes
- sb 204 was adopted by substitution in a 32-21 party-line vote, but failed to garner the two-thirds majority needed to be sent immediately to the governor.

## attendance
the transcript does not mention any quorum or attendance issues.

## adjournment
the session adjourned, but the next session date is not specified. music

title: Lawmakers Day 35 03/25/25
text:
lawmakers day 35 03/25/25 overview:
- the georgia legislature session on march 25, 2025 saw the farewell of senator brandon beach, who was tapped to join the trump administration as the new u.s. treasurer. 
- lawmakers passed several notable bills, including hb 92 extending the deadline for counties and municipalities to opt out or rescind an opt-out of property tax homestead exemptions, and hb 340 banning cell phones in k-8 schools during the school day.
- the session also featured emotional moments, including a tearful thank-you from a representative who was let go from his job after voting against a bill.

key actions:
- **hb 92**: extends deadline for counties/municipalities to opt out or rescind opt-out of property tax homestead exemptions
- **hb 340**: bans cell phones in k-8 schools during school day, allowing school systems to set their own policies
- **sb 123**: defines chronic absenteeism in schools and requires attendance review teams
- **sb 42**: increases penalties for sex trafficking of minors
- **sb 110**: revises definition of child neglect in georgia code

bills introduced (first reading): none mentioned

notable moments:
- tearful farewell from a representative who was let go from his job after voting against a bill
- representative quoted bible verse jeremiah 29:11 after being let go

votes:
- hb 92 passed 52-2
- hb 340 passed 54-2 
- sb 123 passed 160-1
- sb 42 passed unanimously
- sb 110 passed 100-69

## overview
this interview discusses the recent passage of tort reform legislation in georgia, the ongoing efforts to address insurance reform, and the georgia chamber's strategic plan for the state's economy through 2050. key topics include the impact of the tort reform bill, the need to attract more insurers to the georgia market, and the georgia chamber's long-term vision for the state's workforce and infrastructure.

## key actions
no specific bills were mentioned as being passed or referred.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced during this discussion.

## notable moments
- the interview highlights the 20-year history of tort reform efforts in georgia, noting that the initial reforms were often overturned by the courts.
- georgia chamber president chris clark emphasized the importance of involving "hardworking georgians" and the "grassroots" in the tort reform push, not just business executives.
- clark expressed confidence that the state will be more vigilant in defending the recent tort reform legislation against legal challenges, unlike previous efforts.
- the discussion touched on the chamber's hope that insurance reform and increased competition will help stabilize insurance rates in georgia.

## votes
no specific votes were mentioned.

## attendance

## adjournment

of passing, really the first piece of tort reform or lawsuit abuse reform.

title: Lawmakers Day 31 03/13/25
text:
lawmakers day 31 03/13/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia lawmakers day 31 03/13/25 session:

**overview:**
the session featured a mix of lighthearted debates on bills designating official state colors and heritage horses, as well as more serious discussions around school psychologist licensing, pesticide disclosure requirements, and the use of song lyrics as evidence in the high-profile prosecution of rapper young thug.

**key actions:**
**hb 81:** allows school psychologists to work across state lines with equivalent licensing.
**hb 167:** allows the use of fluorescent pink in addition to orange for hunting attire.
**sb 139:** allows the city of mulberry to annex certain parcels of land in gwinnett county.
**sb 138:** waives gwinnett county's sovereign immunity in providing services to mulberry.
**sb 144:** prevents pesticide manufacturers from being held liable for undisclosed health risks beyond fda requirements.

**bills introduced (first reading):** none noted.

**notable moments:**
- debate on the appropriate "shade of pink" to be used for hunting attire.
- democrats opposing the mulberry annexation and gwinnett county service bills, arguing it was a "free berry" approach.
- passionate discussion around the use of song lyrics as evidence in the young thug prosecution, with a democratic representative joining the opposition.

**votes:**
- hb 81 passed 48-2.
- hb 167 passed unanimously.
- sb 139 passed 96-74 along party lines.
- sb 138 passed along party lines.
- sb 144 passed 101-58.

**attendance:** quorum maintained.

title: 1/23/24 Senate Committee on Ethics
text:
1/23/24 senate committee on ethics overview:
the georgia senate committee on ethics discussed several bills related to elections and voting procedures, with a focus on preventing the implementation of ranked choice voting in the state.

key actions:
- **sb 355**: prohibits the use of ranked choice voting in georgia, except for military and overseas voters.

bills introduced (first reading):
- sb 355 by senator robinson
- sb 358 by senator burns

notable moments:

title: Lawmakers Day 39 04/02/25
text:
lawmakers day 39 04/02/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia legislature floor session transcript:

**overview**:
this was a busy day 39 of the georgia legislative session, with lawmakers racing to pass as much legislation as possible before the session ends. the session featured partisan debates on voting bills, as well as recognitions and emotional moments around school safety and mental health.

**key actions**:
- **hb 397**: controversial voting bill that passed along party lines, with democrats criticizing it as an attempt to disenfranchise voters.
- **sb 17**: "ricky and lisa's law" adding clarifying language to a school safety bill passed earlier.
- **sb 185**: bill banning state funds for gender-affirming care for transgender prisoners, prompting a walkout by democratic lawmakers in protest.
- **sb 214**: bill requiring paper ballots in elections, which will have to wait until the next session since it missed the crossover day deadline.

**bills introduced (first reading)**: no new bills mentioned.

**notable moments**:
- emotional testimony from a legislator about their child's fear of school shootings.
- georgia first lady marty camp joined the session to discuss the 988 mental health crisis hotline.
- walkout by democratic lawmakers in protest of sb 185.
- recognition of longtime legislative cameraman wesley nichols for his 25 years of service.

**votes**:
- **hb 397**: passed 33-23 along party lines.
- **sb 17**: passed unanimously.
- **sb 185**: passed, prompting a democratic walkout.

**attendance**: no specific quorum notes provided.

title: Lawmakers Day 38 03/31/25
text:
lawmakers day 38 03/31/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia legislature floor session transcript:

**overview**
the session on day 38 (03/31/25) of the georgia legislative session saw heated debates on several bills, including the pediatric safe storage act (hb 1), a bill banning transgender athletes from female sports (sb 1), and a bill creating financial incentives for local school boards to approve charter school petitions (sb 82). the session also included the recognition of 33 black legislators elected during reconstruction and the consideration of the state's fiscal year 2026 budget.

**key actions**
- **hb 303**: bill to place a memorial on capitol grounds honoring 33 black legislators elected in 1868 during reconstruction.
- **sb 93**: georgia early literacy act, creating new guidelines for teaching reading to young students.
- **sb 1**: bill banning transgender girls from participating in girls' sports and requiring changing rooms to be separated by sex assigned at birth. passed 100-64.
- **sb 82**: bill creating financial incentives for local school boards to approve petitions for new charter schools and penalizing school systems that repeatedly deny charter school proposals. passed 107-62.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
- none mentioned

**notable moments**
- before the presentation of hb 268 (school safety bill), senator bill callisert read the names of appalachia high school shooting victims and asked for a moment of silence.
- democrats opposed sb 1, calling it a "manufactured crisis" and criticizing the bill for targeting individuals rather than addressing real problems.
- republicans argued that sb 1 protects the integrity of women's sports and ensures fair competition.

**votes**
- hb 268 (school safety bill): passed 45-9
- sb 1 (transgender sports ban): passed 100-64
- sb 82 (charter school incentives): passed 107-62

**attendance**
- quorum was present for the proceedings.

**adjournment**
- the session adjourned for the day, with committees scheduled to meet the next day and the house and senate floor sessions scheduled to resume on wednesday. hv1 is a democratic bill called the pediatric safe storage act.

title: Lawmakers Day 36 03/27/25
text:
lawmakers day 36 03/27/25 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia lawmakers day 36 03/27/25 session:

**overview:** the session was marked by several notable actions, including passing bills to allow terminally ill patients access to experimental treatments, create a scholarship grant program for youth in foster care, and codify access to in vitro fertilization. there was also debate over a bill to criminalize artificial intelligence videos designed to interfere with elections, and a partisan resolution to investigate alleged illegal campaign contributions by the new georgia project.

**key actions:**
- **sb 72:** allows terminally ill patients to access experimental treatments
- **sb 85:** creates a scholarship grant program for georgia youth in foster care
- **sb 233:** adds individuals with first-hand experience with addiction to the behavioral health reform and innovation commission
- **sb 9:** criminalizes artificial intelligence videos designed to interfere with elections (passed 152-12)
- **sb 69:** sets regulations around third parties financing lawsuits (passed 98-69)
- **sb 105:** allows veterinarians to give pet health advice
- **hb 428:** codifies access to in vitro fertilization

**bills introduced (first reading):**
- hb 106, hb 310, hb 423, hb 60

**notable moments:**
- visit from the house speaker's chief of staff, terry england, who was recovering from a farming accident
- debate over sb 9, with arguments that ensuring election integrity is the "most important thing" lawmakers can do for constituents

**votes:**
- sb 9 passed 152-12

title: Lawmakers Day 32 03/18/25
text:
lawmakers day 32 03/18/25 overview:
- the georgia general assembly session on day 32 (march 18, 2025) saw the introduction of several bills and resolutions, including some controversial measures.
- the session featured debates over bills related to maternal mortality, tax relief for timber farmers, and expanding farmland ownership, as well as resolutions praising republican politicians.

key actions:
- **hb 111**: allows the maternal mortality review committee to access psychiatric and medical records related to maternal mortality cases, in an effort to lower the state's maternal mortality rate.
- **hb 223**: provides tax relief for timber farmers who suffered economic losses from hurricane helene.
- **hb 90**: allows farmers to own up to 4,000 acres of farmland and receive lower tax rates, pending voter approval to change the state constitution.
- **sb 6**: allows the sale of fentanyl test strips to the public and excludes them from drug paraphernalia classification.
- **sb 55**: requires companies to pay georgians with intellectual disabilities at least the minimum wage, phasing out sub-minimum wage programs.

bills introduced (first reading): none mentioned in the transcript.

notable moments:
- governor kemp appointed barbara rivera-holmes as the new commissioner of labor, replacing the late bruce thompson.
- the senate debated and passed resolutions praising former congressman and current va secretary doug collins, as well as president donald trump, despite some democratic opposition.

votes:
- **hr 32 and hb 90**: passed unanimously
- **sr 245 (doug collins)**: passed
- **sr 246 (donald trump)**: passed along party lines 31-18

attendance: no quorum notes mentioned.

- tanner discussed plans for a new 16-bed crisis stabilization and diagnostic center for the idd population, which will provide comprehensive medical and psychiatric care.
- he also mentioned opening pilot group homes to step down individuals from hospitals and getting approval from cms for new medicaid placement options for the "hard to place" idd population.
- tanner highlighted workforce challenges, with dbhdd losing over 1,200 employees during covid, and efforts to boost recruitment and retention, including partnerships with universities.

**overview:**
the press conference focused on announcing the filing of senate bill 433, also known as "rio's law", which aims to create a specialty license plate to help law enforcement and first responders better identify and interact with individuals with autism or developmental disabilities during traffic stops and emergencies. the bill also requires basic training for georgia peace officers on how to best interact with these individuals.

**key actions:**
**sb 433 (rio's law):** creates a specialty license plate to help law enforcement and first responders identify individuals with autism or developmental disabilities, and requires basic training for georgia peace officers on interacting with these individuals.

**bills introduced (first reading):** 
- sb 433 (rio's law)

- connor tomlinson, star of the netflix show "love on the spectrum", spoke as an autistic advocate in support of the legislation.
- chairman lumpston of the house pledged to champion the bill in the house, drawing on his own law enforcement experience.

title: Sen Jackson Press Conference on Gun Violence | 01/20/2026

## overview
senator jackson introduced new legislation, sb 413, which would allow victims of gun violence to break their leases without penalty in order to move to a safer location. this builds on her previous work passing sb 75, which allowed victims of stalking to break leases. the press conference featured testimony from a trauma surgeon, dr. amber hannah, and a gun safety advocate, heather hallett, emphasizing the need for this legislation.

## key actions
**sb 413**: allows victims of gun violence to break their leases without penalty in order to move to a safer location.

this press conference by georgia senate president pro tempore larry walker outlines the republican majority's legislative priorities for the 2026 session, focused on addressing the high cost of living and reigniting the "american dream" for hardworking georgians.

- walker expresses concern that affordability issues have caused many georgians to feel that the "american dream" is slipping beyond their grasp.

the session focused on the importance of leaders taking time for personal reflection and prayer, especially during times of cultural and political divisions. there was no substantive legislative action detected.

- rep. can trail introduced guest chaplain matt lawson, who spoke about the need for leaders to "watch over their own souls" through prayer and reflection.

- lawson emphasized that in times of crisis, the people under a leader's care need them to maintain spiritual grounding through regular prayer and solitude, following the example of jesus.

a quorum was present, with members being instructed to vote green to signify their attendance.

this session featured the passage of two notable bills, sb 431 and sb 346, related to education and veterinary medicine. there was also discussion of several other bills and some routine procedural matters.

**sb 346**: increases the membership of the state board of veterinary medicine and authorizes a registered veterinary technician member.

title: Georgia House - Day 40 (2026-04-04)
text:
georgia house - day 40 (2026-04-04) ## georgia house - day 40 am session (april 4, 2026)

### overview
opening morning session of the final day (day 40) of the 2026 legislative session. heavy focus on morning orders, recognitions, and beginning bill passage.

### key legislation passed
- **hb 582**: allows abuse victims to present evidence in defense; includes hb 384 defining police oath violations as felonies/high aggravated misdemeanors
- **hb 266**: major veterans tax relief - virtually eliminates state income tax on veteran retirement income; includes police foundation tax credits
- **hr 7**: road naming resolution honoring george a. seat true locke jr. (amended to add hr 328 for chief jeffrey e. turner i-75 dedication)

### morning orders & recognitions
- **pastor jay williams** (chaplain): reflected on significance of 40-day sessions, compared to biblical 40-day periods
- **rep. stetson**: thanked colleagues for support during cancer treatment; recognized new macon county sheriff carlo spelton
- **spelman college glee club**: celebrated 100th anniversary
- **kindle ray johnson**: recognized as youngest certified farmer in the usa
- **ocarian dwight perry memorial**: ice cream truck safety legislation (hr) in his memory

### announcements
- rules committee meeting at 1:30 pm (room 341)
- intergovernmental coordination committee in room 406
- first annual sine die block party in liberty plaza (1-6 pm)

### session notes
- final day atmosphere with celebrations and recognitions
- multiple family visitors in gallery for sine die you

## overview
the session focused on the discussion and passage of senate bill 144, which aims to limit the ability of city housing authorities to operate outside municipal boundaries without authorization from the local governing body.

## key actions
**sr 84**: resolution creating a joint study committee on airport infrastructure and improvements.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced.

## notable moments
- rep. jasper presented sr 84, highlighting the importance of airports to georgia's growth and the need for a strategic plan.
- rep. earheart presented sb 144, explaining that it would require housing authorities to get approval from the governing body of areas outside city limits where they want to develop housing projects.
- rep. jones and rep. atomis asked clarifying questions about the jurisdiction and definition of housing projects under sb 144.
- rep. wilkerson spoke in support of sb 144, stating it was about ensuring local control over housing authority operations.

## votes
- sr 84 was adopted with a vote of 156-0.
- no recorded votes were taken on sb 144.

title: Georgia House - Day 36 (2026-03-28)
text:
georgia house - day 36 (2026-03-28) here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia house session transcript:

## overview
the session focused on passing a bill to add the word "courage" to the pledge of allegiance to the georgia state flag, as well as a bill to provide relief for victims of human trafficking who were convicted of crimes as a result of being trafficked.

## key actions
**sb 152**: adds the word "courage" to the pledge of allegiance to the georgia state flag.  
**sb 565**: allows victims of human trafficking to petition to have their sentences vacated if the crimes were committed as a direct result of being trafficked.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected.

## notable moments
- representative gullett presented sb 152, arguing that the cardinal virtue of courage should be included in the state flag pledge alongside wisdom, justice, and moderation.
- there was some discussion around whether adding "courage" to the pledge would require changes to the state seal, which the representative clarified would not be necessary.
- the house voted to pass sb 152 by a vote of 125-23.
- representative hagen presented sb 565, which aims to provide relief for victims of human trafficking who were convicted of crimes as a result of being trafficked.

## votes
**sb 152**: passed 125-23

## attendance
no quorum issues noted.

## adjournment
the session adjourned, with the next session date unspecified. you

title: Georgia House - Day 22 (2026-03-02)
text:
georgia house - day 22 (2026-03-02) here is a summary of the georgia house session from 2026-03-02:

**overview**
this session focused on substantive legislation, including a bill to combat human trafficking and another to allow certain medical professionals to incorporate as a professional corporation.

**key actions**
**hb 823**: requires the georgia department of driver services to permanently revoke the commercial driver's license (cdl) of an individual convicted of using a commercial motor vehicle to commit the offense of trafficking a person for labor or sexual servitude.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
- hb 816: allows chiropractors and medical doctors to incorporate as a professional corporation when practicing together.
- hb 578: authorizes the department of human services and its contractors to receive conviction data on volunteers, students, and interns to ensure they pass criminal background checks.

**notable moments**
- representative houston gaines presented hb 823, noting georgia's high rates of child sex trafficking and the need for additional tools to fight this issue.
- representatives expressed bipartisan support for hb 823 and the efforts of first lady marty kemp to combat human trafficking.
- there was discussion of a recent incident in columbus where truck drivers helped rescue a young trafficking victim.

**votes**
- hb 823 passed with a vote of 166-0.
- hb 578 passed with a vote of 166-0.

**attendance**
a quorum was present, and no issues with attendance were noted.

**adjournment**

**overview**:
this session focused on several key pieces of legislation, including bills related to solar power financing, increased penalties for cruelty to children, and updates to insurance and fire safety regulations.

**key actions**:
- **hb 300**: provided protections for landowners entering into solar power facility agreements and maintained the balance of solar energy integration in the state's power mix.
- **hb 1022**: the "colton mcneal act" increased penalties for first and second-degree cruelty to children, especially involving disabled minors.
- **hb 984**: updated practices of the department of insurance and office of the safety fire commissioner.

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
no new bills were introduced during this session.

- representative sainz presented hb 1022, the "colton mcneal act", to increase penalties for cruelty to children cases, which were described as some of the most difficult to prosecute.
- representative lumston presented hb 984 to update insurance and fire safety regulations.

**votes**:
- hb 300 passed 146-0.
- hb 1022 passed 158-0.
- no other recorded votes mentioned.

**attendance**:
no quorum issues were noted.

title: Georgia House - Day 2 (2026-01-12)
text:
georgia house - day 2 (2026-01-12) ## georgia house of representatives - day 2, 2022 session (january 12, 2022)

### overview
second day of the 2022 session, the morning after georgia bulldogs' national championship victory. session opened with championship game highlights played in the chamber.

### key actions
- **sr 362**: joint resolution notifying governor that general assembly has convened (adopted)
- committee of notification appointed (8 members including rep. meeks, rep. bonner, chairman hogan)

### bills introduced (first reading)
- **hb 870-874**: local bills for bullock county board of commissioners, bullock county board of education, bibb county redistricting

### morning orders & memorials
- **officer ricky tottenson**: moment of silence for newton police department officer (18-year veteran, school resource officer known as "officer t") who died in the line of duty
- coweta delegation presented the memorial

### announcements
- **local redistricting**: chairman tankersley reminded members about january 7th memo on local redistricting procedures; bills affecting 2022 elections should pass by first week of february
- **senator cleveland memorial**: originally scheduled for friday, postponed to april
- **keep georgia wild day**: scheduled for january 13th in the rotunda at 9 am with governor and conservation groups
- **state of the state**: governor's address scheduled for thursday, january 13th

### notable moments
- championship game celebration video played at session opening
- speaker joked about rep. gullet attending a different bowl game (and losing)
- birthday recognition: chairman jan tankersley

### adjournment
adjourned until thursday, january 13th at 10 am (state of the state day). you

title: Georgia House - Day 1 (2026-01-10)
text:
georgia house - day 1 (2026-01-10) ## georgia house of representatives - day 1, 2022 session (january 10, 2022)

### overview
opening day of the 2022 legislative session, notable for coinciding with the georgia bulldogs' national championship football game.

### key actions
- **hr 568**: notified senate that house has convened
- **hr 569**: called joint session for governor's address (scheduled for thursday at 10:45 am)
- **hr 570**: established session schedule - out tuesday (jan 11), reconvene wednesday at 11 am, thursday/friday at 10 am, then budget hearing recess

### bills introduced (first reading)
- **hb 843**: property tax exemptions amendment
- **hb 846-849**: traffic/road safety and child abuse reporting
- **hb 850**: holiday observances
- **hb 851-853**: inmate policies and detention conditions
- **hb 854**: incorporation of city of buckhead
- **hr 529**: national park services concerns

### notable moments
- rep. west cantrell (term-limited after 8 years) delivered scripture reading from romans 12
- multiple references to georgia bulldogs championship game that evening
- birthday recognitions: rep. karen bennett, rep. betsy holland, rep. beth camp, rep. wiltson, rep. derek jackson

### attendance
full session, journal confirmed without objection.

### adjournment
adjourned until wednesday, january 12th at 11 am to accommodate championship celebrations. you

the session focused on the review and discussion of the state budget, house bill 68, which outlines the allocation of approximately $36-37 billion in taxpayer funds over the next 12 months. the senators highlighted the challenges of the current economic climate and the need for fiscal responsibility, while also recognizing the efforts of the house and senate budget committees in crafting the budget.

no specific bills were passed or referred during this session.

title: Lawmakers Day 28 2025
text:
lawmakers day 28 2025 overview:
the georgia legislature had a busy 28th day session, with a number of notable bills being passed or introduced. the session was marked by a bipartisan approach on some school safety measures, while more partisan debates emerged around a proposed income tax cut and a bill seeking to limit local firearm regulations.

key actions:
**sb 17**: mandates mobile alert panic systems for schools and requires mapping of school properties to aid emergency response.
**sb 61**: adds new charges that students could be prosecuted for in superior court, including terroristic threats.
**sb 179**: requires sharing of student disciplinary history when transferring schools and holds parents legally responsible for not disclosing suspensions.
**sb 163**: rescinds local city and county laws over guns and weapons, entrusting regulation exclusively to the state.
**hb 111**: reduces the state's flat income tax rate from 5.39% to 5.19%.
**hb 112**: provides a one-time tax rebate of $250 for single taxpayers and $500 for married couples.
**hb 657**: annexes 45 small parcels of land into the newly formed city of mulberry.

bills introduced (first reading):
no new bills were introduced during this session.

notable moments:
- senator colton moore's impassioned speech advocating for his bill sb 163 to rescind local firearm regulations.
- debate between republicans and democrats over the merits of the income tax cut bill hb 111.

votes:
- sb 17, sb 179 passed unanimously.
- sb 61 passed 33-22 along party lines.
- sb 163 passed 33-23 along party lines. 
- hb 111 passed 110-60, mostly along party lines.
- hb 112 passed unanimously.
- hb 657 passed 98-76, mostly along party lines.

attendance:
the session maintained a quorum throughout the proceedings.

adjournment:
the legislature adjourned for the day. the next session date was not specified. you are looking at a live view from under the gold dome where this house is working hard
on the 28th day of the legislative session.

sb 17, also known as ricky and alyssa's law, named after two victims in high school
shootings, would mandate mobile alert panic systems for schools to alert local responders

that every school property in the state be mapped so that data is provided when an incident happens
in real time. our folks and friends in the public safety community know where to go to find the
assailant, where to go save lives, where to evacuate people. the bill passed unanimously.
senate bill 61 would add new charges that a student could be prosecuted for in superior court
including terroristic threats.
i think it's important to point out at this point as well that the bill preserves the existing
authority for a da at any time before indictment after investigation and for cause to decline the
prosecution and superior court and bring the case to juvenile court for those between the ages
of 13 and 17. democrats were less enthusiastic about this bill as it passed 33 to 22 along
party lines. and senate bill 179 requires the sharing of a student's disciplinary history
when transferring schools and holds parents legally responsible for not disclosing a current suspension.

rules meeting for day 28 of the 2025 session here is a summary of the georgia rules meeting for day 28 of the 2025 session:

**overview**: this session featured a variety of bills being considered, including measures related to voting, black women's history, age discrimination, recovery support services, student loan forgiveness for veterinary technicians, and enforcement of transit lanes in atlanta.

**key actions**:
- **hb 502**: allows parents with young children to go to the front of the line when voting.
- **hb 146**: designates april as black women's history month.
- **hb 10**: removes arrest photos of those never convicted from "remove for pay" websites.
- **hb 311**: removes the age cap of 70 for working individuals.
- **hb 657**: certifies peer specialists and defines recovery community organizations.
- **hb 217**: extends a dual achievement program allowing high school dropouts to earn diplomas and technical certificates.
- **hb 88**: provides student loan forgiveness for veterinary technicians.
- **hb 638**: allows marta to use cameras to enforce bus rapid transit lanes.
- **hb 442**: allows students 25 days of school absence for film industry work.

**bills introduced (first reading)**: no new bills were introduced during this session.

- hb 502, hb 146, hb 10, hb 311, hb 657, hb 217, hb 88, hb 638, and hb 442 all passed with no recorded opposition.

title: Rules Meeting Special Session of the 2025 Session
text:
rules meeting special session of the 2025 session here is a summary of the georgia rules meeting special session of the 2025 session based on the transcript provided:

**overview**
the session focused on the introduction and consideration of several bills, primarily related to licensing requirements, venue regulations, homeowner associations, sexual assault kit retention, women's golf week designation, and rural hospital programs. there was some discussion and debate around one of the bills regarding potential discriminatory effects.

**key actions**
- **hb 512**: caps fees charged by homeowner associations and provides for alternate dispute resolution before liens can be placed.
- **hb 626**: extends the retention period for sexual assault kits from 20 to 30 years.
- **hb 718**: designates the first week of april as women's golf week in georgia.
- **hb 662**: allows rural emergency hospitals to participate in the georgia heart program.
- **hb 566**: protects artists from ai-generated replicas of their work without permission.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
- hb 185: modernizes and streamlines licensing requirements for dieticians and nutritionists.
- hb 671: restricts minors from attending sexually explicit performances at venues.

**notable moments**
- there was a discussion around hb 671 and concerns about potential discriminatory effects on the lgbtq+ community. the bill's sponsor agreed to work further on the legislation.

**votes**
no recorded votes were mentioned in the transcript.

**attendance**
the transcript does not provide any information about quorum or attendance.

title: Rules PM meeting for Day 27 of the 2025 Session

**overview:** the meeting focused on discussing and passing a rules substitute for house bill 268, a school safety bill, as well as reviewing a room substitute for house bill 651 regarding school zone cameras.

**key actions:**
- **house bill 268:** a rules substitute was passed, which adds provisions for generating reports on de-identified student records and coordinating mental health services and threat assessment teams in schools.
- **house bill 651:** a room substitute was presented, which addresses signage, speed detection, citation amounts, and other aspects of school zone cameras.

title: Rules meeting for Day 27 of the 2025 Session
text:
rules meeting for day 27 of the 2025 session here is a summary of the georgia rules meeting for day 27 of the 2025 session:

**overview:**
the rules committee heard presentations on several bills, including measures related to tax credits for workforce development programs, veteran license plates, and regulation of private water companies. the committee also discussed routine code revision and clean-up legislation.

**key actions:**
- **hb 7**: provides a $4,000 income tax credit for graduates of workforce readiness programs employed in high-tech jobs in rural counties
- **hb 583**: allows totally disabled veterans or those with a high level of disability to obtain a second free license plate for their spouse or another vehicle
- **hb 718**: designates the first week of april as "women's golf week" in georgia
- **hb 351**: clarifies the permitting process for solid waste landfills to prevent future lawsuits
- **hb 371**: raises the maximum annual appropriation for capital outlay projects from $300 million to $375 million

**bills introduced (first reading):**
no new bills were introduced.

title: Appropriations Meeting for Day 27 of the 2025 Session
text:
appropriations meeting for day 27 of the 2025 session here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia appropriations meeting for day 27 of the 2025 session:

## overview
this session focused on considering resolutions to compensate individuals who were wrongfully incarcerated. several cases involving issues like self-defense, manufactured evidence, and juror misconduct were discussed.

## key actions
**hr 119**: resolution to compensate mario stinchcomb for 18 years of wrongful incarceration after he was exonerated by the fulton conviction integrity unit.  
**hr 118**: resolution to compensate michael woolfolk for wrongful incarceration after he was exonerated.  
**hr 129**: resolution to compensate daryl lee clark for 25 years of wrongful incarceration due to issues like manufactured evidence and witness coercion.  
**hr 128**: resolution to compensate joseph "joey" samuel watkins for wrongful incarceration due to juror misconduct and buried exculpatory evidence.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none noted.

## notable moments
- discussions of the tragic circumstances and injustices faced by the individuals who were wrongfully incarcerated.
- appreciation expressed for the previous support these resolutions received in the house.
- descriptions of the various issues that led to the wrongful convictions, including self-defense evidence, coerced testimony, and brady violations.

## votes
- hr 119 (stinchcomb compensation): passed
- hr 118 (woolfolk compensation): passed  
- hr 129 (clark compensation): passed
- hr 128 (watkins compensation): not voted on

## attendance
a quorum was present to conduct business.

## adjournment
the session adjourned, with the next session date not specified. good morning, it is a little a little past eight and we do have a quorum, so i would like to get started after i ask chairman meeks to open us up with prayer.

title: Press Conference with Senator Jones & Former Senator Jason Esteves | 12/8/2025
text:
press conference with senator jones & former senator jason esteves | 12/8/2025 here is a structured markdown summary of the key points from the georgia legislature floor session transcript:

## overview
the transcript highlights a press conference with senator jones and former senator jason estevez discussing the impending healthcare crisis in georgia due to the expiration of federal aca subsidies. they call on republican leadership to take action to protect healthcare access and affordability for georgians.

## key actions
**sb 192**: the georgia health insurance affordability and consumer protection act, introduced by former senator estevez to address the healthcare coverage gap when federal subsidies expire.

## bills introduced (first reading)
no new bills were introduced in this transcript.

## notable moments
- senator jones criticizes republicans for refusing to address the healthcare affordability crisis and failing to pass solutions like sb 192.
- former senator estevez shares his personal experience seeing the impacts of the healthcare crisis as the husband of a nurse practitioner. he pledges that as a future leader, he will fight to expand medicaid and lower insurance premiums.
- kiana randi gregory and her mother marilyn share how the loss of healthcare subsidies has impacted their family.

## votes
the transcript indicates that sb 192 was introduced but not passed, implying it failed to receive enough votes.

## attendance
no specific quorum or attendance details provided.

## adjournment
the transcript does not mention the session adjourning or provide details on the next scheduled session. i want to thank everybody for coming today.

title: Sen. Islam Parkes Press Conference on Expiring SNAP Benefits | 10/29/2025
text:
sen. islam parkes press conference on expiring snap benefits | 10/29/2025 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia sen. islam parkes press conference on expiring snap benefits | 10/29/2025 session:

## overview
this press conference addressed the impending expiration of snap (supplemental nutrition assistance program) benefits for nearly 1.4 million georgians, including over 640,000 children. the speakers, including sen. nabila islam parkes, rachel kent (a single mother), and alicia rivera from the nonprofit georgia feeding families, called on governor brian kemp to declare a state of emergency and use the state's budget surplus to continue providing snap assistance to affected families.

## key actions
none detected.

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected.

## notable moments
- sen. islam parkes emphasized that food is not optional and this is a "humanitarian crisis unfolding in real time." 
- rachel kent, a single mother, shared her personal struggles of relying on snap benefits to feed her son and called on gov. kemp to use the state's surplus to support families in need.
- alicia rivera from georgia feeding families discussed the increased demand for assistance at food banks and the need for urgent action to address the crisis.
- former state senator jason estevez, who is running for governor, expressed his support for the snap program and criticized the current leadership for not taking action to help georgians in need.

## votes
none detected.

## attendance
quorum was present, as senators and community representatives participated in the press conference.

## adjournment
no formal adjournment, as this was a press conference rather than a legislative session. thank you so much for being here today. i am state senator nabila islam parks and
i'm here today with rachel kent and her son sterling. they rely on food
assistance from snap benefits. we're also here with alicia rivera who is with
georgia feeding families, a food bank in georgia, and also my former colleague
state senator jason estevez. in just a matter of days, nearly 1.4 million
georgians, including over 640,000 children, could lose access to the food they
depend on through snap. this is not some distant policy debate. this is a
a humanitarian crisis unfolding in real time and on our watch. let me be clear. food is not optional.
this is not about politics. this is about children eating dinner. this is about seniors being
able to take their medicine with food. this is about parents not having to choose between groceries
or gas to get to work. georgia is blessed, blessed to have 14.6 billion dollars in a surplus.
what we have is what we need and we have it to protect these families. we just need the
will to do it. and that's why we're calling on governor camp to declare a state of emergency.
let's get georgia families the food assistance they need, governor.
you often say we are the number one state to do business, but we must also be the number
one state for families, for children, for seniors.
let's show that economic strength is not something we brag about.
it is something we use to take care of our own.
we are here to extend a hand and come up with solutions, and it is time for all of us
to step up and do what georgians always do in a crisis.
we roll up our sleeves, we pull together, and we get the job done.

title: Sen. Jones & Sen McLaurin Press Conference on Free Speech | 9/25/2025
text:
sen. jones & sen mclaurin press conference on free speech | 9/25/2025 here is a structured markdown summary of the georgia senate jones & mclaurin press conference on free speech from september 25, 2025:

**overview**
senators jones and mclaurin, along with advocacy groups, condemned the trump administration's ongoing attacks on free speech and the lack of action from senate republicans to defend the first amendment. they highlighted specific cases of viewpoint discrimination, media censorship, and the targeting of activists and dissenting voices.

**key actions**
no specific bills were mentioned.

**bills introduced (first reading)**
none detected.

**notable moments**
- sen. jones detailed how the trump administration has "weaponized the fcc" against media outlets, sued law firms over clients they represent, and restricted discussion of topics like slavery.
- cair representative asuka mahmoud described activists being "abducted" and detained by ice for speaking out against the "palestinian genocide."
- sen. mclaurin contrasted the biden administration's voluntary requests to social media companies to the trump fcc's threats to force abc affiliates to "take action" against jimmy kimmel for his free speech remarks.
- mclaurin expressed optimism that the american people value free speech and will not "take this repression by the trump administration lying down."

**votes**
no votes mentioned.

**attendance**
no quorum notes.

**adjournment**

title: Sen. Josh McLaurin Press Conference | 9/19/2025
text:
sen. josh mclaurin press conference | 9/19/2025 here is a structured summary of the key points from the georgia sen. josh mclaurin press conference transcript:

**overview:**
- sen. mclaurin held a press conference to discuss the impending deportation of journalist mario guevara by the trump administration's board of immigration appeals (bia), an executive agency. this is seen as part of a broader pattern of the administration's attacks on free speech and the press.

**key actions:**
- the bia has issued an order to deport mario guevara, a journalist who has been legally residing in the us for decades, with no notice or explanation other than a 13-year-old deportation order that had been paused.
- guevara has an active federal court case seeking habeas relief, which the bia is proceeding to ignore.

**bills introduced (first reading):** 
- none detected.

**notable moments:**
- sen. mclaurin is joined by richard griffiths, a representative of the georgia first amendment foundation and former immigrant journalist, who speaks about the troubling pattern of attacks on the press under the trump administration.
- griffiths expresses how "dispiriting" it is to see a journalist thrown out of the country for doing their job.
- there is an emergency hearing underway in federal court, with the aclu and other organizations seeking a temporary restraining order to stop the deportation and allow guevara's case to play out.

**votes:**
- none detected.

**attendance:**
- no quorum notes.

**adjournment:**
- no adjournment information provided. all right. good afternoon, everybody. thank you for being here on short notice. my name is josh mcquarran.
i serve in the state senate for north fulton county. we're here today because the board of
immigration appeals, which is an executive agency under the trump administration, has issued an
order to deport journalist mario guevara today with no notice, with no explanation, except that
13 years ago, mario guevara had a deportation order that has been paused since then. since then,
he has been legally in the united states doing journalism spending time with his family
and just being a citizen without a criminal record. and he was arrested on some trumped-up charges
that have since been dropped in june and was put into ice detention at that time and has remained
in ice detention awaiting his opportunity to clear his name and go back to living as a productive
and responsible citizen in the united states where he has been for decades. today with no warning
the board of immigration appeals decided that it would dredge up that 13-year-old order and send
mr. guevara out of the country. the board of immigration appeals decided to do this,
notwithstanding that mario guevara has an active case in federal court where he's seeking
habeas relief. to try to prove, again, that he's entitled to stay in the united states under
the same rules and practices that he has been for decades, ignoring that that federal court
proceeding was happening, the bia proceeded anyway, and his lawyers are currently scrambling
to figure out what the bia ruling was even all about in terms of what its legal basis was,
or why it's happening right now. so i want to make something very clear for anybody who's
listening. this is not just a court in the traditional sense. it's not the judiciary
with senate confirmed judges. this is an executive agency, the board of immigration appeals,
with judges that are appointed by other executive officials responsible to the trump administration,
who have made this dec

title: Sen. Wicks Press Conference on National Guard Deployments | 9-8-2025
text:
sen. wicks press conference on national guard deployments | 9-8-2025 here is a structured summary of the key points from the georgia sen. wicks press conference on national guard deployments:

**overview**
this press conference focused on the concerning issue of potential federal deployment of the national guard in georgia, which sen. wicks and other legislators condemned as unconstitutional and a threat to democracy. the speakers strongly opposed using the military against american citizens.

**notable moments**
- sen. wicks, a retired army officer, passionately argued that the national guard uniform should "never be used to intimidate or divide" and that its purpose is to "protect and serve," not be misused against the people.
- rep. bell compared the current situation to the dystopian fx series "american horror story" and urged the national guard to "come not with rifles but with rations" to help the poor and suffering, not oppress them.
- rep. jackson, another veteran, warned that using the national guard for domestic law enforcement would violate the posse comitatus act and disrespect the distinct roles of the military and law enforcement.

**opposition to guard deployments**
the legislators strongly condemned any potential federal deployment of the national guard in georgia, calling it unconstitutional, dangerous, and a violation of states' rights under the 10th amendment. they called on the governor and all georgians to resist this "federal overreach."

**conclusion**
the speakers passionately defended the principles of democracy, freedom, and the constitution, urging resistance against any actions that would "trample on the dignity of free men and women." they declared that "this is not nazi germany" and that georgia must remain a "beacon of democracy." good afternoon. thank you for being here. i'm senator kenya wix district 34. as
a retired army officer with 30 years of service to this nation and now as a
georgia senator, i feel deeply responsible to speak on the issues that strikes
our core of our democracy and the values we all share. in light of the recent
deployment of the georgia national guard, let me be clear. not only is this
this misguiding is unconstitutional, dangerous and inconsistent with the very oath that every
service member has sworn to uphold.
it dishonors the service, undermines the constitution, and erodes the trust that binds our communities
together.
i have served this country for 30 to 3 decades.
i wore the uniform because i believed in the promise,
the promise of liberty, of opportunity for all.
i have seen the weight of the sacrifices
that has made by the soldiers and the families.
the uniform should be never used to intimidate or divide.
it should be used to only protect and serve.
let me end with this.
the strength of the american has never come
from turning the soldiers against our people.
it comes from defending the constitution,
protecting freedoms, standing for what's right,
even when it's difficult.
i will continue to oppose the efforts
of misusing the national guard.
and i urge my fellow colleagues, the fellow citizens,
to do the same.
our democracy demands it, the value commands it,
and our people deserve it.
thank you.
i will be followed by a representative eric bell.
thank you, senator.

title: 4/3/2025 | Democratic Caucus Press Conference on HB127
text:

**overview**:
the democratic caucus strongly opposed hb 127, describing it as a bill that would take georgia "backwards" on issues of race, discrimination, and civil rights. they accused the republican party of being "afraid" to condemn slavery and the confederacy.

**key actions**:
- **hb 127**: a bill that was originally about providing extra sick days for teachers, but was amended by republicans to include "dei" (diversity, equity, and inclusion) provisions that the democrats opposed.

**bills introduced (first reading)**:
none mentioned.

- democrats said they were prepared to fight for "5-6 hours" to either defeat the bill or amend it, but were denied that opportunity.
- democrats criticized republicans for not allowing amendments that would have affirmed that slavery was a cause of the civil war and that evolution should be discussed.

no specific votes mentioned.

no quorum notes provided.

title: 3/12/2025--GLBC--Press Conference on SB67
text:
3/12/2025--glbc--press conference on sb67 overview:
- this press conference focused on opposition to sb 68, a bill that georgia legislators argue would unfairly limit victims' ability to seek justice in court, particularly for survivors of sex trafficking and drunk driving accidents.

key actions:
- **sb 68**: bill that would restrict victims' ability to sue businesses, which legislators argue would protect corporate interests over victims' rights.

bills introduced (first reading):
- none mentioned

notable moments:
- emotional testimony from sex trafficking survivors recounting their "repeated rape, repeated sadimization, repeated beatings, repeated torture and torment at the hands of abusers."
- legislators argue the bill is "poorly drafted" and proponents could not articulate a scenario where sex trafficking victims could seek justice under the bill.
- legislators call on the governor and republican leadership to work with them to improve the bill to better balance business and victim interests.
- accusations that the governor and republican leadership have targeted and tried to silence victim advocacy groups like mothers against drunk driving who oppose the bill.

the press conference addressed the recent passage of senate bill 120 in the georgia senate, which bans promoting, supporting or maintaining any programs or activities that advocate for diversity, equity and inclusion (dei) at post-secondary institutions. speakers strongly criticized the bill, arguing it is an assault on american and georgia values of inclusion and diversity.

title: Sen. Tillery Press Conference on Eliminating State Income Tax | 07-24-2025
text:
sen. tillery press conference on eliminating state income tax | 07-24-2025 ## overview
sen. tillery announced his plan to introduce legislation in the 2026 legislative session to eliminate the georgia state income tax. he will chair a study committee to determine how to responsibly achieve this goal while protecting the state's priorities. the senator emphasized this is not a debate about whether to eliminate the tax, but rather how to do it.

## key actions
none detected

## bills introduced (first reading)
none detected

## notable moments
- sen. tillery stated his commitment to eliminating the georgia state income tax during the 2026 legislative session.
- he will chair a study committee to determine the path forward, working closely with the lieutenant governor.
- the senator argued that eliminating the state income tax is about competitiveness, economic freedom, and allowing georgians to keep more of their money.
- he pointed to 9 states that have already eliminated their state income tax as examples georgia can learn from.

## votes
none detected

## attendance
no quorum notes provided.

## adjournment
no adjournment details provided. well, thank you all first of all for being here today. i appreciate that.
in the 2026 legislative session, i will introduce legislation to take the georgia state income tax rate to zero.
let me repeat that for you one time. during the georgia 2026 legislative session, i will introduce legislation to take georgia's income tax rate to zero.
this may not happen overnight, but i'm committed to delivering on this goal in a way that protects
our state's core priorities, health care, education, infrastructure and public safety.
my mission is simple, eliminate georgia's income tax and its entirety.
and over the next several months, i will chair study committees, work closely with my
colleagues, and of course consult with lieutenant governor bert jones to chart a realistic
and responsible path to eliminate georgia's income tax.
let me be clear, my role as chair is not to debate whether we do
away with the state income tax, it's to determine how we will do
away with the state income tax.
georgia's state income tax was started roughly 80 years ago
during the great depression, and for a large part of that time,
it remained at 6% largely unquestioned.
it's only been in the past decade under republican leadership
that we've seen that percentage rate finally begin to trickle down.
and while that's progress, it's just a start.
because we don't operate in a vacuum, you see our neighboring states like north carolina
and south carolina are quickly working to reduce their state income tax.
and nine states in our nation have already completely done away with theirs.
and these aren't just red states and they're not just blue states.
you've got wyoming, washington, new hampshire, texas, tennessee, and of course florida.
and when folks mention florida, the first thing they do is say, well, that's because of
tourism, but tourism doesn't explain how tennessee did it.
and it doesn't explain how new hampshire did it.
and while some credits will warn you that doing away with the state income ta

text:
2-27-2025 | glbc priorities press conference overview:
the georgia legislative black caucus held a press conference to outline their legislative priorities for the 2025-2026 session. the priorities focused on expanding healthcare access, affordable housing, supporting black-owned businesses, ensuring equitable education, criminal justice reform, and protecting voting rights and black cultural heritage.

key actions:
**sb 50**: peach care plus act of 2025 to expand medicaid under the affordable care act
**hb 149**: health mothers act to address high maternal mortality rates, especially among black women
**sb 65**: mandates kindergarten before 1st grade
**sb 54**: establishes statewide database to track school safety threats
**hb 135**: prohibits housing discrimination based on hairstyles associated with race or ethnicity
**hb a**: renews state investment tax credit and removes barriers for investors

bills introduced (first reading):
- legislation to define housing habitability standards based on federal definitions
- restrictions on corporations buying up homes in georgia

notable moments:
- chair nikki merritt outlined the glbc's key priorities across healthcare, housing, economic empowerment, education, public safety, and advocacy.
- whip terry cummings and vice chair doreen carter provided additional details on the legislative agenda.
- references were made to the trump administration's education reforms and the new conservative white house administration's proposed cuts to arts/culture funding.

votes: 
no specific votes mentioned, but several bills were described as passed or in committee.

attendance:
no quorum notes provided.

adjournment:
no adjournment time given, but this appears to be an ongoing press conference. good afternoon, everyone. we're going to go ahead and get started.
thank you all for joining this afternoon. my name is senator nikki merritt,
and i have the pleasure of serving as chair of the georgia legislative black caucus.
and i'm very happy to share our 2025, 2026 priorities. as you guys know, we're in the
the biennial so it's every two years so this would carry us for the next two years.
so whatever we don't have of our priorities that we don't get completed this year, we
will continue that work next year.
and at the georgia legislative black caucus, we remain committed to policies that uplift
black communities across the state.
we're fighting to expand health care access.
that is just one of our priorities, pushing for full medicaid expansion, enhanced maternal
health programs and increased community-based mental health services. in the area of housing,
we are advocating for incentivizing affordable options, instituting, rent stabilization,
and strengthening tenant protections. on the economic front, our agenda supports black-owned
businesses through tax incentives, grants, and low interest loans, improving workers' rights,
and financial education programs. for education, our next priority, we demand equitable,
k through 12 funding, increased support for our hbcus, expanded scholarships, and a statewide
inclusion of black history, curriculum, and public safety and justice, our next priority.
we are calling for reforms. we call for trust-based policing, comprehensive background checks,
and accountability measures to protect black communities.
lastly, advocacy extends to improving environmental justice,
expanding and protecting voting rights,
and preserving black culture through dedicated funding
for the arts and community spaces.
and with that, i'm going to turn it over to our caucus
whip representative, terry cummings,
and she is going to share some more of our priorities.
